scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-208 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-208 is a star with 1.16 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.31 times its radius. It is located 2528.78 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.37 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-208 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-208 system


Kepler-208 b

Kepler-208 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-208 b is 3.307 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 b is 1.630 that of Earth. At 3.307 Earth masses, Kepler-208 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-208 c

Kepler-208 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-208 c is 2.512 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 c is 1.390 that of Earth. At 2.512 Earth masses, Kepler-208 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-208 d

Kepler-208 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-208 d is 1.870 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 d is 1.200 that of Earth. At 1.870 Earth masses, Kepler-208 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-208 e

Kepler-208 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-208 e is 2.795 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 e is 1.480 that of Earth. At 2.795 Earth masses, Kepler-208 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-208, which contains 4 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-20 e - First Planet Smaller than Earth Discovered by Kepler
